SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

gr.forth.ics.graph
Interface Tuple

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
All Known Subinterfaces:
Edge, Node
public interface Tuple
extends Serializable

Entity that can be decorated with custom entries. It works similarly to a standard java.util.Map. It features:

  • Type-safe methods for a variety of types
  • Internal support for weak entries (see putWeakly(Object, Object))
  • A single property (getValue(), setValue(Object)) that can be accessed without key (so, much faster than a normal key-value entry).
  • Inheritance of entries (see setParentTuple(Tuple)
    • A Tuple supports for weak entries through putWeakly(Object key, Object value) method. A weak entry is an entry that is eventually (automatically) removed when its key is no longer reachable (that is, eligible for garbage collection). This removes the need for "cleanup" style methods in algorithms that decorate entities with data. Implementation note: in the standard implementation of Tuple (gr.forth.ics.graph.concrete.TupleImpl), weak entries are actually faster than normal, strong entries. Also, a single internal map is used to store both types of entries, to save memory (both in terms of memory used by the maps themselves and for storing the references to the maps).

    Method Detail

    put

    Object put(Object key,
           Object value)
    Puts a regular key-value entry to this tuple. Null keys and values are allowed.

    Returns:
    the old value of this key, if any (or null).

    get

    Object get(Object key)
    Returns the value associated with the specified key. If no value is found, and this tuple has a parent (see setParentTuple(Tuple)), the parent is queried with the same key. Null is returned if no value is ultimately found.

    remove

    Object remove(Object key)
    Removes a key-value entry, either regular or weak. Returns the value of the entry, if found (or null).

    has

    boolean has(Object key)
    Returns true if an entry is found (in this tuple, or in its parent) with the specified key, either regular or weak.

    putWeakly

    Object putWeakly(Object key,
                 Object value)
    Puts a weak key-value entry to this tuple. This entry will be automatically removed when the key becomes unreachable (and eligible for garbage collection). Returns the old value of the specified key, if there was one (or null).

    getValue

    Object getValue()
    Gets the value associated with this tuple.

    setValue

    Object setValue(Object value)
    Associates a value with this tuple. Returns the old value that is replaced.

    getBoolean

    Boolean getBoolean(Object key)
    Returns the value of the given key as Boolean.

    getInt

    int getInt(Object key)
    Returns the value of the given key as int. (The real value needs only to be a Number, not necessarily an Integer).

    Throws:
    NullPointerException - for a non-existent key

    Returns the value of the given key as long. (The real value needs only to be a Number, not necessarily a Long).

    Throws:
    NullPointerException - for a non-existent key

    copyInto

    void copyInto(Tuple tuple)
    Copies every regular (non-weak) entry of this tuple, to the specified tuple.

    Throws:
    NullArgumentException - when tuple is null

    equalValues

    boolean equalValues(Tuple other)
    Returns true if, and only if, other is a Tuple that has exactly the same regular entries. That is, weak entries are not taken into consideration. Entries are tested by the equals() method of keys and values.

    keySet

    Set<Object> keySet()
    Returns a modifiable set that contains all keys of regular (non-weak) entries. Adding or removing elements to/from this set has no effect on the tuple. Does not contain keys from parent tuple.

    getParentTuple

    Tuple getParentTuple()
    Returns the parent tuple of this tuple, or null if no parent has been set.

    setParentTuple

    void setParentTuple(Tuple parent)
    Sets the parent tuple of this tuple. This tuple will inherit all entries (regular and weak) of its parent, and every entry defined in this tuple, which has a key that is contained in the parent tuple, effectively overrides the parent entry. This facility can be used as a mechanism to share common attributes between tuples. Note: Pay attention not to create cyclic inheritance between tuples, or else get() operations may end up in an infinite loop.

    asMap

    Map<Object,Object> asMap()
    Returns a live Map view of this tuple. The Map will contain all the entries of this tuple, including weak entries. Any modifications to the returned map will be delegated to this tuple. The returned map has value semantics, i.e. its equals/hashCode methods are based on its entries. Entries are also supported in this map. If an entry is added, a regular entry is added in this tuple. If an entry is removed, the respective entry is removed from this tuple. If an entry's setValue(Object) method is called, the respective entry in this tuple also changes value.
